Overview

Shadowman is an exploration of how standard web technologies can be leveraged to facilitate discovery, and availability of distributed data stores such that multiple, geographically distributed stores can contribute to a central base of knowledge, without requiring all data is served from a centrally accessible network location. Distributed systems offer a valuable collection of capabilities, such as regional availability and redundancy. Establishing common glue between these distributed components is essential in realizing a cohesive constellation of knowledge. Ensuring consistency and availability remains a challenge due to regional distribution of data owners, temporal differences, everyday technical challenges, such as outages, network latency, time synchronization, and the often, inherent lack of transactional boundaries in distributed systems. Often, systems fail to recognize the unique behaviors of data and users when performing query and replication. Shadowman intends to recognize these “behavioral” data as key metrics in determining optimal query plans and distribution strategies. Additionally, system configurations often introduce new technologies, communication protocols, or network configurations, which can potentially tax existing IT infrastructure and staff. Shadowman’s use of standardized and web-friendly technologies and protocols, such as web sockets, CometD and Oort, aims to simplify installation and maintenance and facilitate a more rapid introduction of multi-site, distributed capabilities into existing environments.

Shadowman intends to meet these challenges by:

  • Establishing processes and shared probabilistic hashes informing data locality. Federated query capability is aware of data locality per fact and provides optimized query paths thereby reducing network traffic, minimizing false positives and eliminating false negatives. Current implementation utilizes a distributed bloom filter.

  • Offering transactional fact integrity guarantees by ensuring that the freshest fact is considered before a remote agent accepts a proposed mutation. This accounts for unbounded latency and does not require complex time synchronization components. Current implementation performs fact integrity enforcement via vector clock-based locking, resident within the database process as a user defined function.

  • Defining an asynchronous fact persistence API that allows the developer to precisely and dynamically define fact distribution, per-read per-write operation

  • Providing a simulation and monitoring framework allowing for distributed scenarios to be defined, executed and observed against running Shadowman quorum

  • Observing request patterns and tuning replication and caching strategies based on

    • request origin and frequency
    • data volume
    • false positives
    • data location
    • static configuration

Use Cases

  • P2P network of lightweight agents with varying degrees of network connectivity, power, and storage capacity contributing to shared knowledge base of situational awareness:

    • Warehouse picking and packing personnel
    • Field agents of multiple disciplines
    • Maritime and submariner actors
    • Mobile infantry

  • Distributed enterprise composed of centralized data warehouse and remote fields sites with limited enterprise support

    • Weather stations
    • Military outposts
    • Remote SCADA sensors and controls
